questions.question: What are the four layers of the CSS Box Model, starting from the inside out?

answer_variants.answer: Content, Padding, Border, Margin.

The CSS Box Model consists of: 1. Content (the actual data), 2. Padding (space inside the border), 3. Border (the edge), and 4. Margin (space outside the border). Understanding this is critical for layout calculation.
The layout engine computes dimensions based on four concentric boxes: Content Box, Padding Box, Border Box, and Margin Box. Backgrounds usually extend to the Border Box.
1. Content. 2. Padding. 3. Border. 4. Margin.
Imagine a framed picture. Start with the Photo (Content). Add a white mat around it (Padding). Add the Frame (Border). Place it on the wall with some distance from other frames (Margin).
Content -> Padding -> Border -> Margin

The Content is defined by `width/height`. Padding pushes the border away from the content. Border is the visible edge. Margin pushes other elements away from the border. When calculating strict space on screen, all four must be summed unless `box-sizing` modifies the behavior.
The stuff inside, the breathing room inside, the line around it, and the breathing room outside.
User Agent default styles typically apply a Margin to block elements (like `body` or `p`), but Padding is usually 0. Borders are `none` by default.
The CSS box model is essentially a box that wraps around every HTML element. It consists of: margins, borders, padding, and the actual content.

questions.question: What is the crucial difference between `box-sizing: content-box` and `box-sizing: border-box`?

answer_variants.answer: `content-box` adds padding/border to the width; `border-box` includes them in the width.

In `content-box` (default), if you set width to 100px and padding to 10px, the total width is 120px. In `border-box`, the total width remains 100px, and the content shrinks to accommodate the padding. Developers prefer `border-box` for intuitive sizing.
`content-box`: `width` = content width. `border-box`: `width` = content + padding + border. This prevents layout breaking when adding padding.
Default is `content-box`. `border-box` forces the padding and border to be calculated inside the width.

Content Box: You buy a 100 sq ft house, then build walls OUTSIDE it (total size grows). Border Box: You buy a 100 sq ft plot, and build walls INSIDE it (usable space shrinks, but total size is fixed).
`border-box` includes padding/border in the defined width; `content-box` excludes them.

The CSS specification defaults to `content-box` for historical reasons. However, widespread best practice involves a 'Global Reset' applying `box-sizing: border-box` to `*` to ensure that a `50%` width element literally takes up 50% of the container, regardless of its border thickness.
Standard CSS math is weird: standard width adds up. `border-box` makes the math easy: width means the total width.
`box-sizing` does not include Margin. Margins are always additive (outside the box). Use `calc(100% - 20px)` if you need to account for margins in a fluid layout.
Content-box is the default. Width and height properties includes only the content. Border-box includes the padding and border.

questions.question: What are the two main characteristics of a `display: block` element?

answer_variants.answer: It starts on a new line and takes up the full width available.
A block-level element always starts on a new line and extends to fill 100% of the parent container's width (unless a specific width is set). Examples include `<div>`, `p`, and `h1`.
Block formatting context: New line, `width` defaults to `auto` (100%), and vertical margins collapse (Margin Collapsing).
1. Starts on a new line. 2. Takes up the full width of the container.
It's like a selfish person on a park bench. They insist on their own bench (new line) and sprawl out to take the whole thing (full width).
New line + Full Width.
Block elements respect `width`, `height`, `padding`, and `margin`. In contrast, Inline elements ignore vertical margins and width/height properties.
It acts like a paragraph. It breaks the line before and after, and stretches all the way across.
You can change a block element's behavior with `display: inline` or `flex`, but natively it follows the Block Formatting Context rules.
A block-level element always starts on a new line and takes up the full width available (stretches out to the left and right as far as it can).

questions.question: What happens if you set `width` and `height` properties on an element with `display: inline`?

answer_variants.answer: Nothing; the properties are ignored.
`display: inline` elements (like `<span>` or `<a>`) ignore width and height properties. Their size is determined solely by their content. To size them, you must switch to `inline-block` or `block`.
Inline elements are part of the text flow. They accept horizontal padding/margin, but vertical dimensions (`height`, `width`, `margin-top`) have no effect on the document flow.
The browser ignores width/height on inline elements.
It's like trying to resize a single word in a sentence. You can't make the word 'The' 500 feet tall without breaking the sentence structure, so the rule is ignored.
They will have no effect.
This is a common trap. Beginners try to resize a link with `width: 100px`. It fails. The fix is `display: inline-block`, which keeps the element in the text flow but allows box-model sizing.
It won't work. Inline things are just text. You can't give a specific size to a piece of running text.
Replaced inline elements (like ``) ARE exceptions. They are inline but have intrinsic dimensions, so `width` works on them. But generic `` does not.
A width or height property has no effect on inline elements.
`display: none` removes it from layout (no space). `visibility: hidden` hides it but keeps the empty space.
`display: none` removes the element from the Render Tree entirely, causing a reflow. `visibility: hidden` renders the box but makes the pixels transparent, maintaining the layout footprint.
`display: none`: Element is gone. `visibility: hidden`: Element is invisible, occupies space, and technically still exists in the Accessibility tree (sometimes) and DOM.
`display: none` takes 0 space. `visibility: hidden` takes up normal space but is invisible.
`display: none` is leaving the room. `visibility: hidden` is putting on an invisibility cloak but standing in the same spot (people bump into you).
Display none kills the space. Visibility hidden preserves the space.
Event listeners (like click) do not fire on `visibility: hidden` elements, though they occupy space. `opacity: 0` is similar to visibility hidden but allows events and transitions.
One deletes it from the page shape. The other just turns it invisible like a ghost.
A third option is `opacity: 0`. Unlike visibility: hidden, opacity: 0 elements are focusable and clickable. `visibility: hidden` removes focusability.
display:none hides an element, and it will not take up any space. visibility:hidden hides an element, but it will still take up the same space as before.

questions.question: What is the primary usage difference between a Class selector `.name` and an ID selector `#name`?

answer_variants.answer: IDs are unique (one per page); Classes are reusable (many per page).

Semantically, an ID must be unique within a document and identifies a single entity. A Class classifies multiple elements that share style or behavior. CSS Specificity also differs: ID is much stronger than Class.
ID: Unique identifier, selects 1 element, high specificity (1-0-0). Class: Group identifier, selects N elements, medium specificity (0-1-0).
Class starts with `.` and is reusable. ID starts with `#` and is unique.
ID is a Social Security Number (Unique Person). Class is a Uniform or Job Title (Many people can be `Doctor`).
Use ID for one thing; use Class for many things.
Browsers are lenient; they will style multiple elements with the same ID, but this is invalid HTML and breaks JavaScript referencing (`getElementById` only returns the first match).
ID is for a specific guy. Class is for a team of guys.
Due to the high specificity of IDs (making them hard to override), modern CSS methodologies (BEM, OOCSS) strongly discourage using IDs for styling at all. Classes are preferred.
The id selector is used to select one unique element. The class selector selects elements with a specific class attribute.

questions.question: What does the Universal Selector `*` do, and what is its performance implication?

answer_variants.answer: It selects every single element on the page. It can be slow if used excessively.

The `*` selector matches any element type. It is commonly used for Box-Sizing resets. Theoretically, it is slow (as the browser must traverse the entire DOM), but modern engines optimize it well especially for unconditional resets.
It is a wildcard matching the name of any element type. It has 0 specificity (0-0-0). Useful for resets but avoid using it in complex descendant chains like `.container *` as it defeats optimization.
It acts as a wildcard to select all elements.
It's like shouting 'Everyone!' in a crowded room. Everyone listens.
Selects all elements. Example: `* { margin: 0; }`

Early browsers struggled with the performance of `*`. Today it is standard practice for `box-sizing: border-box`. However, combining it (`div * span`) is still expensive because CSS parses Right-to-Left (Basic Selector Matching).
The Star means 'Everything'. Use it to strip margins off everything at the start.
Pseudo-elements (`::before`, `::after`) are NOT selected by `*` alone in older specs, though typically resets include `*, *::before, *::after` explicitly.
The universal selector (*) selects all HTML elements on the page.
Child elements behave like their parents (e.g., inheriting font properties) unless told otherwise.

Inheritance is the mechanism where certain properties set on a parent element are passed down to its children. Text-related properties (`color`, `font`, `line-height`) usually inherit, while layout properties (`margin`, `padding`, `border`) do not.
The propagation of property values from parent to child. The `inherit` keyword can force non-inherited properties to inherit. Computed values are passed down the DOM tree.
It means children receive the style values of their parent. E.g., setting font on `body` affects `p`.
Like genetics. If the Parent has Blue Eyes (Color), the Child has Blue Eyes. But if the Parent wears a Hat (Border), the Child is not born wearing a hat.
Fonts inherit; Boxes don't.
You can control this with `all: inherit` or `all: initial`. Inheritance streamlines CSSâ€”you only set the font-family once on the `body` tag instead of on every paragraph.
If you set the text color on the Body, all the text inside becomes that color automatically.
Anchors `<a>` are a notable exception; strict user-agent styles for links (blue/underline) usually stop them from inheriting the parent text color unless you explicitly set `color: inherit`.
Inheritance controls what happens when no value is specified for a property on an element.

questions.question: In the simplest terms, which selector has the highest specificity: ID, Class, or Tag?

answer_variants.answer: ID > Class > Tag.
Specificity defines the weight of a rule. The hierarchy is: IDs (100) > Classes/Attributes/Pseudo-classes (10) > Elements/Pseudo-elements (1). Inline styles beat all of them (1000).
It is calculated as a tuple (A, B, C). A=ID count, B=Class count, C=Tag count. An ID always beats any number of classes.
ID (`#id`) is higher than Class (`.class`), which is higher than Tag (`div`).
Tag is a suggestion. Class is a Rule. ID is a direct Order from the boss.
ID beats Class beats Tag.
This hierarchy is why we avoid IDs for styling. If you use an ID, you cannot override it later with a Class, forcing you to use `!important` or another ID, leading to 'Specificity Wars'.
The ID is the boss. The Class is the manager. The Tag is the employee.
The Universal Selector `*` has 0 specificity. It is overridden by everything.
ID selector has higher priority than Class selector, which has higher priority than Element selector.

questions.question: What is the effect of the `!important` declaration?

answer_variants.answer: It forces a style to apply, overriding almost all other rules regardless of specificity.

`!important` overrides the natural cascading order. It is the highest specificity tier (beaten only by another `!important` later in the source or user/browser overrides). It should be used sparingly as it breaks maintainability.
It creates a separate cascade origin. `Author !important` > `Author Normal` > `User Normal` > `User Agent Normal`. However `User !important` (Accessibility) beats `Author !important`.
It makes the CSS property take precedence over all other valid rules.
It's the nuclear button. Use it only when absolutely necessary, because once you use it, normal diplomacy (Cascading) stops working.
Forces the rule to win.

If two conflicting rules both have `!important`, the conflict is resolved by standard specificity. Using it too much results in unmaintainable code where you have to add `!important` everywhere to change anything.
It screams 'Use this style no matter what anyone else says!'.
Legitimate use case: Overriding 3rd party library inline styles that you cannot edit directly.
The !important rule overrides any other style declarations.
